issue.description:
IBC SECTION 1012 RAMPS 1012_2 Slope (part of means of egress).
Ramp slope is 10.0%. The maximum slope for the ramps is 8.0%.
issue.title: Too Steep Ramp: 10.0%

suggestions.action: Regrade the ramp to a slope of 8.0%.
suggestions.reasoning: The current ramp slope of 10.0% exceeds the IBC maximum of 8.0%. Regrading will ensure compliance.

suggestions.action: Introduce intermediate landings to segment the ramp.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding landings can break the slope into compliant sections without extending the ramp.

suggestions.action: Install a mechanical lift as an alternative.
suggestions.reasoning: A lift provides accessibility without altering the ramp, suitable for space-limited areas.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.0.3 tread length is 0.20 m. The minimum length for the tread is 0.28 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.3: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Increase the tread length of Stair.0.3 from 0.20 m to 0.28 m to comply with regulations.
suggestions.reasoning: The current tread length of 0.20 m does not meet the minimum requirement of 0.28 m, which is necessary for safety and compliance.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair layout to incorporate a spiral design, allowing for a more compact footprint while achieving the required tread length.
suggestions.reasoning: A spiral design can offer a creative solution to space constraints while ensuring each tread meets the minimum length requirement.

suggestions.action: Introduce a staggered tread design, alternating between 0.28 m and 0.20 m, to create visual interest and maintain compliance.
suggestions.reasoning: A staggered tread design can add an artistic element to the staircase while ensuring that the overall design meets safety standards.

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Underside of stair should be shielded to protect visually impaired persons from accessing it inadvertently.
issue.title: Stair.0.3

suggestions.action: Install a protective barrier under the stair to prevent accidental access by visually impaired individuals.
suggestions.reasoning: The stair's reduced vertical clearance poses a risk, and a barrier can prevent unintended access.

suggestions.action: Integrate a tactile warning surface at the base of the stair to alert visually impaired individuals.
suggestions.reasoning: A tactile surface can serve as a sensory warning, enhancing safety by alerting individuals to the presence of the stair.

suggestions.action: Install motion-activated lighting under the stair to increase visibility and awareness.
suggestions.reasoning: Enhanced lighting can improve visibility and awareness, reducing the risk of accidental contact with the stair.

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Underside of stair should be shielded to protect visually impaired persons from accessing it inadvertently.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Install a protective barrier under the stair to prevent accidental access.
suggestions.reasoning: The stair's reduced vertical clearance poses a risk to visually impaired individuals. A barrier will prevent inadvertent access.

suggestions.action: Incorporate a tactile warning surface at the base of the stair.
suggestions.reasoning: A tactile surface will alert visually impaired individuals of the approaching hazard, enhancing safety.

suggestions.action: Design an artistic canopy that doubles as a protective shield under the stair.
suggestions.reasoning: An aesthetically pleasing canopy can serve as both a visual enhancement and a safety feature, preventing accidental access.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair SStair.1448 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing of Stair SStair.1448 to meet the 0.90 m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is below the required 0.90 m, which can be resolved by expanding the landing area to ensure compliance with safety standards.

suggestions.action: Reconfigure adjacent spaces to integrate a wider landing for Stair SStair.1448.
suggestions.reasoning: By adjusting the layout of adjacent spaces, the landing can be expanded without compromising the overall design, ensuring compliance and maintaining aesthetic integrity.

suggestions.action: Introduce a mezzanine level to create additional space for a compliant landing.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding a mezzanine level can provide the necessary space to expand the landing, enhancing both functionality and visual appeal while adhering to safety regulations.

issue.description:
504.3 Open Risers
Stair SStair.1448 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the 0.90m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is insufficient. By extending the existing slabs, compliance can be achieved.

suggestions.action: Reconfigure the staircase layout to provide additional landing space.
suggestions.reasoning: Rearranging the connected spaces can create room for a wider landing without altering the main structure.

suggestions.action: Install a cantilevered extension to the landing.
suggestions.reasoning: A cantilevered platform can increase landing width efficiently, maintaining structural integrity and aesthetics.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair SStair.1456 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.2.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing of Stair SStair.1456 to meet the 0.90 m width requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than the required 0.90 m, which can be resolved by adjusting the stair's dimensions.

suggestions.action: Reconfigure the adjacent walls to create additional space for the stair landing.
suggestions.reasoning: By modifying the position of the surrounding walls, more space can be allocated to the stair landing, ensuring compliance.

suggestions.action: Introduce a cantilevered landing extension to increase the width without altering the existing structure.
suggestions.reasoning: A cantilevered design can provide the necessary width while maintaining the current spatial layout.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.0.1 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.1: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Reduce riser height to 0.18 m for Stair.0.1.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height of 0.18 m, which could pose a safety risk.

suggestions.action: Introduce a split-level landing to adjust riser height.
suggestions.reasoning: A split-level landing can help distribute the elevation change more evenly, reducing the riser height to comply with standards.

suggestions.action: Incorporate a gradual ramp alongside the stairs.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding a ramp can provide an alternative path that meets accessibility standards, reducing reliance on the non-compliant risers.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.2.1 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.2.1: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Reduce riser height from 0.20 m to 0.18 m for Stair.2.1.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height exceeds the maximum allowable height, which can lead to non-compliance with building codes.

suggestions.action: Introduce a gradual slope at the base of Stair.2.1 to adjust riser height.
suggestions.reasoning: A slope can seamlessly transition the height difference, maintaining aesthetic and functional integrity.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair layout to incorporate a landing, redistributing riser heights.
suggestions.reasoning: A landing can break the stair run, allowing for compliant riser heights while enhancing user safety.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.3.2 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Reduce the riser height of Stair.3.2 to 0.18 m.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height of 0.18 m. Adjusting the riser height will bring the stair into compliance with the standard.

suggestions.action: Introduce a gradual slope to reduce the effective riser height.
suggestions.reasoning: By incorporating a slight slope, the perceived riser height can be reduced, maintaining user comfort and compliance without major structural changes.

suggestions.action: Install a decorative overlay to adjust the riser height.
suggestions.reasoning: Adding a decorative overlay can subtly adjust the riser height while enhancing the aesthetic appeal of the staircase, achieving compliance creatively.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.2.2 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.2.2: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Reduce riser height to 0.18 m for Stair.2.2.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height exceeds the maximum allowed by 0.02 m, which can be adjusted to meet compliance.

suggestions.action: Introduce a gradual slope between steps to reduce riser height.
suggestions.reasoning: Incorporating a slight slope can effectively reduce the perceived riser height, enhancing accessibility while maintaining structural integrity.

suggestions.action: Add an intermediate landing to split the stair flight.
suggestions.reasoning: An intermediate landing can break the stair into two sections, effectively reducing the riser height per section and improving user comfort.

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Stair SStair.1448 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.2

suggestions.action: Widen the landing to meet the 0.90m clearance requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is insufficient, and widening it will ensure compliance with clearance standards.

suggestions.action: Install a cantilevered extension to the landing.
suggestions.reasoning: A cantilevered extension can provide the necessary clearance without extensive structural changes.

suggestions.action: Reroute traffic to an alternative compliant pathway.
suggestions.reasoning: Rerouting can be a cost-effective solution if other compliant pathways are available.

issue.description:
504.3 Open Risers
Stair SStair.197 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.1

suggestions.action: Widen the landing of Stair SStair.197 to meet the 0.90 m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width of Stair SStair.197 is less than the required 0.90 m, which is non-compliant. Adjusting the width will ensure compliance with safety standards.

suggestions.action: Integrate a cantilevered extension to the landing to achieve the required width.
suggestions.reasoning: By creatively extending the landing using a cantilevered design, the stair can meet the width requirement without major structural changes.

suggestions.action: Redesign the stair layout to incorporate a spiral section, optimizing space and meeting width standards.
suggestions.reasoning: A spiral section can provide the necessary width while offering a unique architectural feature, enhancing both functionality and aesthetics.

issue.description:
307.4 Reduced Vertical Clearance
Stair SStair.1114 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.3

suggestions.action: Widen the landing of Stair SStair.1114 to meet the 0.90 m clearance requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is below the required 0.90 m, which can impede safe passage and accessibility.

suggestions.action: Introduce a staggered landing design to creatively expand the clearance without major structural changes.
suggestions.reasoning: A staggered design can provide the necessary clearance while maintaining the existing structural integrity and aesthetic.

suggestions.action: Incorporate a retractable landing extension that can be deployed during peak usage times to ensure compliance.
suggestions.reasoning: A retractable extension offers flexibility, allowing the landing to adapt to varying traffic demands while ensuring safety and compliance.

issue.description:
504.3 Open Risers
Stair SStair.1114 has a landing with clear width of less than the required 0.90 m.
issue.title: Stair.0.3

suggestions.action: Widen the landing of Stair SStair.1114 to meet the 0.90 m requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: The current landing width is less than the required 0.90 m, which can be resolved by expanding the landing dimensions.

suggestions.action: Introduce a cantilevered extension to the landing to achieve the required width.
suggestions.reasoning: By adding a cantilevered extension, the landing can meet the width requirement without major structural changes.

suggestions.action: Redesign the staircase to incorporate a spiral landing that meets the width requirement.
suggestions.reasoning: A spiral landing design can creatively utilize space to meet the width requirement while maintaining aesthetic appeal.

issue.description:
504.2 Treads and Risers
Stair Stair.3.1 riser height is 0.20 m. The maximum height for the risers is 0.18 m.
issue.title: Stair.3.1: 0.20 M

suggestions.action: Adjust riser height to 0.18 m by increasing the number of steps.
suggestions.reasoning: The current riser height of 0.20 m exceeds the maximum allowable height. By increasing the number of steps, the riser height can be reduced to meet the compliance requirement.

suggestions.action: Introduce a split-level landing to divide the stair run into two sections.
suggestions.reasoning: A split-level landing can break the elevation change into two compliant sections, offering a resting point and maintaining the overall design integrity.

suggestions.action: Use thinner tread material to increase step count without altering design.
suggestions.reasoning: By using a thinner tread material, the number of steps can be increased slightly, allowing for a compliant riser height while preserving the existing design layout.

issue.description:
405.2 Slope
Ramp length is 3.00 m and slope is 10.0%. The maximum length for this slope is 1.52 m.
issue.title: Ramp.0.1: 3.00 M

suggestions.action: Shorten the ramp to 1.52 meters.
suggestions.reasoning: The current ramp length of 3.00 meters exceeds the maximum allowable length for a 10% slope, which is 1.52 meters.

suggestions.action: Introduce intermediate landings along the ramp.
suggestions.reasoning: By integrating landings, the slope can be divided into smaller, compliant sections, enhancing accessibility and providing rest areas.

suggestions.action: Reconfigure adjacent spaces to create a winding ramp path.
suggestions.reasoning: Utilizing the lobby or snack bar space can allow for a longer, compliant ramp path without major structural changes.
